name: Hey! Who Threw That Apple? Quiz | People | 10 Questions

questions.text: According to the calendar of the time, when was Sir Isaac Newton born?
questions.explanation:
December 25, 1642.

	His birth date was revised to January 4, 1643 by the Gregorian calendar, which was not in use in England until after his death.

questions.text: Where was Sir Isaac Newton born?
questions.explanation:
Woolsthorpe, Lincolnshire.

	In a bedroom of Woolsthorpe Manor.

questions.text: Sir Isaac Newton and his father shared the same name.
questions.explanation:
True.

	Isaac Newton, the father, died three months before his son was born. Very little is known about him, other than the fact that he was illiterate.

questions.text: His mother married a man called Barnabas Smith, when young Isaac Newton was a toddler. What was his step-father's profession?
questions.explanation:
A church minister.

	His mother and step-father moved away leaving young Isaac in the care of his maternal grandmother, Margery Ayscough.

questions.text: After attending a Grantham school, where did Sir Isaac go to continue studying?
questions.explanation:
Cambridge University.

	Sir Isaac attended Trinity College, Cambridge from 1661.

questions.text: What was the reason for Sir Isaac Newton's return home from Cambridge in 1665?
questions.correct: The University closed because of the Plague
questions.explanation:
The University closed because of the Plague.

	Cambridge University closed due to the Plague, in the summer of 1665, and did not re-open until 1667.

questions.text: In what fields did Newton make revolutionary advances after returning home from Cambridge?
questions.explanation:
Mathematics, optics, physics and astronomy.

	The story of the apple, supposedly took place in the orchard of his home, during that time.

questions.text: What was the short name given to Newton's treatment of physics and its application to astronomy?
questions.explanation:
Principia.

	Newton published these papers in 1687. Their full name was, 'Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica'.

questions.text: Who persuaded Newton to publish these papers?
questions.explanation:
Sir Edmond Halley.

	Sir Edmond would have benefited greatly from Newton's theories.

questions.text: Which of these was not a post held by Sir Isaac Newton?
questions.explanation:
Astronomer Royal.

	Sir Isaac Newton died in March of 1727, in London, England. His work has proved to be not only influential but invaluable through the centuries.
